Hi all,

For those of you that missed it, we wrote a summary of the discuss=
ions that
took place at the AAAI symposium we held last year about how inte=
lligence
can or should be abstracted in artificial intelligence research. T=
he
article includes commentary by keynotes Pierre-Yves Oudeyer, Randall
O=
=E2=80=99Reilly, Risto Miikkulainen and Gary Marcus.

It is difficult to de=
cide what details to include or exclude from a model.
It=E2=80=99s also dif=
ficult to know which fields of AI are blossoming and which are
stagnating. =
It=E2=80=99s even harder to know which fields have long-term potential,
and=
 which might be dead ends. All of those issues were discussed at the
sympos=
ium and a summary of those thoughts are in this article.

The PDF version i=
s available here
<http://sebastianrisi.com/wp-content/uploads/lehman_is2014=
.pdf>.

We hope you enjoy it. Please let us know if you have any questions.=


Best,
Sebastian, Joel, Jeff

--

 summary of the discussions that took place at the AAAI symposium we held l=
ast year about how intelligence can or should be abstracted in artificial i=
ntelligence research. The article includes commentary by keynotes Pierre-Yv=
es Oudeyer, Randall O=E2=80=99Reilly, Risto Miikkulainen and Gary Marcus.<b=
r><br>It is difficult to decide what details to include or exclude from a m=
odel. It=E2=80=99s also difficult to know which fields of AI are blossoming=
 and which are stagnating. It=E2=80=99s even harder to know which fields ha=
ve long-term potential, and which might be dead ends. All of those issues w=
ere discussed at the symposium and a summary of those thoughts are in this =
